sections.title: Introduction
sections.content:
The purpose of this user manual is to provide an overview of the main functions and features of the eRegistrations system and to explain how to create online services.

Description of eRegistrations:
- eRegistrations is a no-code development platform allowing to create online services without programming.
- An online service is a succession of online screens and actions through which:
  - an applicant can fill a form, upload documents, pay and send his request (application file)
  - one or more operators can review the file and approve or reject an application (processing)
  - The applicant data is sent to an online registry
  - A registration certificate is issued
- Online services are visible on the 'public site', also called 'user site' or 'DS' (Display System)
- They are created through an 'administrative site', also called 'BPA' (Business Process Analyzer)

sections.title: A. Description of the entry page
sections.content:
The administrative site, also called BPA (Business Process Analyzer) is the site where online services are created. The BPA requires no programming. Services are built by configuring a succession of screens.

The BPA entry page has 3 main sections:
- 'Header' also called 'instance bar' (the blue bar at the top)
- Side menu (on the left)
- Work space (in grey)

1 The header or 'instance bar'
It consists sequentially of:
- UNCTAD and eRegistrations logo
- 3 buttons FE (front end), BE (back end) and DS (display system). When they are red, it means the corresponding component is getting updated. We can work on the system only when all buttons are green. When you put the cursor over the components name you will see the version number currently running. Versioning is made according to semantic versioning rules.
- 'Logged users' show the number of administrators logged into BPA at that moment.
- When the toggle is switched on, new feature/bug fixes are allowed to come automatically to the applications in the system
- User level 1 and 2 is a toggle button that minimizes and expands display of elements on the side menu bar
- User ID of the administrator logged in
- Choice of language
- Instance settings icon: 1. Settings that will apply to all services, 2. Translations icon, 3. Log-out icon

2 Side menu
This view is accessible only after you have created and entered a service.
- User level 1: Displays only a limited number of elements on the left side menu
- User level 2: Displays more elements, including Tables and Certificate builder

3 Work space
This is the gray area which displays the contents of the elements on the side bar, and where services are built.

sections.title: B. Services
sections.content:
A service is a succession of screens allowing the applicant to obtain one or more registrations.

A registration is any authorization (certificate, permit, clearance, document) issued by a government agency that an applicant wants to obtain.

1. Create a service
A new service can be created by clicking on the 'add' button.
Then a slider opens, where you can type the name of the service and click save.
To activate the service, click on the toggle next to the service name. Green indicates that the service is active. Inactive services will not be available on the public interface.
An inactive service can be archived in the system by clicking on the archive button.
Archived services can be restored by clicking on 'archived services' and clicking on the unarchive button.
A service can be removed from the system by clicking on the cross.
Once a service has been created, one or more registrations must be created and assigned to the service.

2. The Service bar
This is the service bar, just below the instance (blue) bar. This appears when you click on a service from the list of services in the work space.
The service bar consists of:
- The name of the service, that can be edited by clicking on the edit button next to it
- The 'preview service' button: this displays the application file as seen from the user interface
- The 'publish service' button: when a service is published, it becomes available on the public interface. Every time a change is made in the BPA that needs to be reflected on the public interface (DS), the service has to be (re)published.
- The 'see service' button. This opens the service in the public interface (DS), in a new tab
- Service settings icon

sections.title: C. Registration(s)
sections.content:
Registrations are at the core of the eRegistrations system. A registration is any type of authorization (license, permit, registration number, clearance, certificate, etc.) issued by a government institution, for which an applicant will usually need to provide data, documents and fee.

1 Create a registration
Once a service has been created, one or more registrations must be created and assigned to the service. When you create a new registration, it will automatically be added to the service under which it has been created.
Click on the 'add' button on the search bar. A slider opens. Enter registration name, enter short name (a short name is proposed automatically but you can modify it), create.

A registration is defined by the following elements: a. Name, b. Result, c. Data required, d. Documents required, e. Fees, f. Institution in charge.
The 'Registrations' menu tab will allow us to define all elements except the 'data required', which will be defined in the application file tab, in the applicant form.

Result: To add a result, click on '+ Select or add new' under Results. Then click on the 'add' button. A slider opens. Enter the result name (required), choose whether the result is physical or digital ('P' and 'D'), save. In case of digital result, a template can be built (see build certificates). To add an existing result, select from the drop down list.

Documents: To add documents required, click on '+ Select or add new' under Documents. A slider opens. Enter the document name, choose what is expected ('U' - must be uploaded, 'S' - must be shown at front desk, 'M' - must be signed at collection), save.

Fees: To add applicable fees, click on '+ Add new' under Fees. Fixed fees: Enter name, select 'fixed fee' under Fee Type, select currency, enter value, save. Formula fees: select 'Formula' in fee type, save, click on the fee to open it, click on 'click to add formula' under Formula. Drag and drop variables from left side, select arithmetic symbol, add.

Institution: To add the institution involved, click on '+ Select or add new' under Institutions. A slider opens. Enter name, enter URL, save. To add a Unit involved, click on 'Add new' under Involved Unit.

2 Add registration(s) to a service
To add a new registration to a service, click on the service name. Click on the 'Add' button. A slider will open. Enter the name of the registration and click on 'Create'. To add an already created registration, click on 'add to service' from the 'all registrations' list.

sections.title: D. Application file
sections.content:
The application file:
- It is composed of pages/screens through which the applicant will provide the required data, the documents and the fees.
- In general, the application file is composed of the following pages:
  - Guide: a page where the applicant has to answer questions that will allow the system to determine the registrations s/he needs to apply for and, according to the registrations selected, the required data, documents and fees.
  - Form: to enter the required data
  - Documents upload: to upload the required document
  - Payment: a page explaining how and when the required fees can be made, or allowing to pay online
  - Send: a page giving details about the processing of the file once submitted by the applicant
- A very important notion, called 'determinant' is also explained. Determinants allow us to take into account the specific case of each applicant and, in particular, to generate an adapted applicant file format for each user.

sections.title: D.1. The Guide
sections.content:
Questions can be created in the guide to help determine, for each specific user, which documents, fees and data are required.
The guide is defined by three elements: Description (name of the guide question), Form (where guide questions are developed and linked to the requirements and/or application form using determinants), Status.

If your service has a Guide, activate the guide toggle.
To create a question in the Guide, click on the 'Guide' tab in the Application File. Under the 'Form' tab, create questions using the form components that will filter the data, requirements and fees for specific users' case.

Alternative to the guide: the shopping cart.

sections.title: D.2. Determinants
sections.content:
A determinant is a filter allowing to take into account the particular case of each applicant in a service. It determines/triggers: if an applicant is subject to a registration and/or what requirements the applicant must provide to register (data, documents, fees).

2.1. Determinants of the registration
For each registration, an analyst must be able to report/input in the rule engine, in clear language, rules defining who/what are the subjects of the registration. Options: 1) The registration is mandatory to all, 2) The registration is mandatory to specific subjects, 3) The registration is optional to all, 4) The registration is optional to specific subjects. Specific subjects can be defined through determinants or a combination of determinants combined by 'AND' and 'OR' operators.

2.2. Determinants of the requirements
Determinants play a very important role in the application file. They allow to show or hide specific parts of the application form to adapt the form to the particular situation of each applicant. Determinants can be created on the basis of fields/questions in the Guide or in the form and can be applied to any field/block.

To create a determinant on a block, click on the edit button (gear icon). A slider will open. Click on the Determinant tab, Add. Insert name of determinant, choose 'Determinant based on field value' under determinant type, select the relevant field, choose the relevant predicate, select value or choose comparison field, save.

Once created, select and drop the determinant on the right panel under selected determinants, select the behavior of the component (show/hide when determinant condition is true), General Save.

If the field configuration has a determinant, it will be indicated by the letter 'D' in orange color. If there is more than one determinant, the icon will have a dot in the top right corner.

Special cases of Determinants: Empty date field determinant - create a determinant with a selected date time field with predicate '=' or '!=' without selecting any date.

sections.title: D.3. Applicant form
sections.content:
This is the section in the application file where the applicant will provide the required data. The form can be developed and customized in any format based on an analysis of the data.

To create a form, drag and drop any type of required field component from the menu bar into the space below it.

Containers menu consists of: Block, Table, Columns, Field set, Edit grid, Data grid, Tabs. Containers are mainly used to group/put together data that belong to the same class/category.

Blocks separate/segregate the different types of information. Blocks are collapsible. If you do not want your blocks to collapse, disable the 'collapsible' toggle under the general tab.

Table: drag and drop the table component inside the block. Indicate the number of rows and columns.

Columns: will help align the fields. Only up to 12 units are fitted in one row (e.g., 6+6, 4+4+4, 3+3+3+3).

Field set: groups the fields of the same category of data together.

Edit grid: enables replication of the same set of fields within it, and addition of multiple data for the same set of fields. The label can be hidden by activating 'Hide Label' toggle.

Data grid: very much like an edit grid.

Tabs: can make the form more organized. Can be displayed as a side menu (vertical layout). Structure can be nested.

Fields used while building the form: Catalog (drop-down menu), Sub Catalog, Button (various actions: event, custom, open link, open service and data in new tab).

Common properties: Help toggle (tooltips), Advanced toggle (additional features), Hide Label toggle, Placeholder, Tooltip, Prefix and Suffix, Disabled toggle, Hidden toggle, Reusable toggle, Listing value toggle, Allow Spellcheck, Searchable.

sections.title: D.4. Documents
sections.content:
The Documents tab under Application File should be enabled if documents are defined under registration(s) of the service.

If there is a need for the required document to be visible in some other place on the form then the documents tab, there is a way to achieve it:
1. Drag and drop a file upload component onto the desired form
2. Open File upload component edit modal and go to the Data tab. Click on the 'Requirement' dropdown menu. You will be presented with the list of required documents assigned in service registration(s).
3. Pick the required document from the list and click save. Link between the file upload component and the required document was created. Orange hint icon with L is visible in the top right corner.

sections.title: D.5. Payment
sections.content:
If the service has fee(s) applicable (defined under registration(s)), the Payments tab needs to be enabled.

To add the payment component:
- Click on the Form tab and create a hidden block with the Agency Code and Account Head ID components
- Click on edit Agency Code. Under the Data tab, select agencyCode under Field Tags, Save
- For Account Head ID, edit and select accountHeadId under Field Tags under the Data tab, Save
- Under the Payments tab, drag and drop the Payment Providers component from the Custom components tab. Edit the title, Save.

Radio buttons for online and manual payment will be automatically created inside the block.

To show decimals in costs, click on the service settings, under 'pages, buttons and field' tab, enable the toggle for 'Show decimals for costs'.

sections.title: D.6. Send file
sections.content:
This is the declaration and signature page. It can be developed the same way you develop the form.

The declaration can be created using the 'I Swear' component under Custom Components tab.

sections.title: D.7. Focus on some useful functions
sections.content:
a. Copy value of a field to another (prefilling a field)
This tool is useful because the applicant does not have to provide the same details repeatedly. To copy value from another field: Edit text field/number field, Data, under 'copy value from', choose the element from the drop down, Save. The order of elements is Name of the page, Block and Field. If the field configuration has the copy value setting, it will be indicated by the letter 'C' in blue color. CVF works only between fields of the same type.

b. Copy edit grid values to another edit grid using copy value from
To set it up we need two edit grids - source and destination. In the destination edit grid, specify from which edit grid the data will be copied. You can also use a determinant in the destination edit grid copy value from tab.

c. Field tags
Field tags are like bookmarks. We can put the same tag to various fields. It is used for concatenation of different fields. Listing-value: enables the name of the company under 'My Applications' on the user dashboard visible.

d. Use formula with examples
Types of functions available in the formula builder: maxValue, round, Ceil, Floor, Roundup hundred/thousands/hundred thousands, Subtract days/months/years, Add days/months/years, Override year, Override date, Days difference, Weeks difference, Months difference, Years difference, Business days, Working hours, Working time, Penalty months, formatDateDD-MM-YYYY, Grid row counter, Extract Value From Grid.

Examples: 1) Adding years to a date using addYears function. 2) Subtracting two dates using daysDifference function.

e. Input mask
Used in text field component to auto validate characters. Input mask is under 'Validation' tab under 'Basic validation'. Use '9' for digits, 'A'/'a' for letters, '*' for alphanumeric. Multiple masks can be enabled.

f. Blacklist
Used for restricting certain words in a text field. Click on Validation tab, click on Blacklist option. Options: Case sensitive, Exact match, Word match.

g. Extract data from documents
Used to extract data from documents and putting them automatically onto the form. Under a registration, select the document, open edit modal, create model document, upload an example document. The data extractor lists data available for extraction.

sections.title: D.8. Custom classes
sections.content:
Custom class is a feature that can be applied to the fields in the forms. It is used for customizing fields (spacing, alignment, color, size, etc.) or to deploy a function to a particular field.

1. Appearance changing classes: Value like label, Field + Button, Hide, Text right, Align value to right, Highlight block, Background (Blue/Gray/Green/Orange/Red), Fill background, Default notice, Radio Switch, Search results list.

2. Spacing and alignment classes: Remove top space, Space top (label space), Top space/2X/3X, Remove top inner space, Vertical align top/center/bottom, Full height.

3. Datagrid related classes: Datagrid footer, Add/Remove disabled, Datagrid Condensed, Has footer, Width, Datagrid Hide Column Label.

4. Custom classes for Button: Field + Button, Orange/Blue/Green/Red, Disable on success, Show cog during form submit, Light color, Outline button.

5. Custom classes used for certificate layout:
Old certificate styles: Print-big-field, Print-small-field, (Print) Highlight Value, (Print) Certificate, (Print) Document Section, (Print) Documents last section, (Print) Terms and conditions, (Print) Certificate header, (Print) Certificate document title, (Print) Certificate footer.
New certificate styles: Print Page A4, Print text center/right/left, Print center vertical, Print Page top/bottom/horizontal margin small/medium/large, Print corner top/bottom left/right, Print watermark, Print footer distance small/medium/large, Print non latin text, Print color light/dark/brand, Print space xsmall/small/medium/large/xlarge, Print value small/large, Print label small/large.

6. Other custom classes: Payment form component, I-swear component.
subsections: 5. Custom classes used for certificate layout

sections.title: E. BOT builder
sections.content:
A BOT is an automated action performed by the system. There are two types of BOTs:
- data BOT: to exchange data between an eRegistration service and an external system (eg a GDB database)
- document BOT: to display a document on the screen or upload it to the user file. Two types: Display and Upload.

1. Create a BOT
a) Document BOT: Click on BOT Builder tab, click 'add', enter BOT name, select 'Document BOT' under Type. Select category: 'generate and display', 'generate and upload', or 'generate upload display'. Select document. Only one document can be generated under one button.

b) Data BOT: Select 'Data BOT' under Type. Select 'Create' under Categories.

c) Internal BOT: enables the analyst to copy data from one component to another. Can be performed within the same form, between different forms, between grid components, or between forms in different services. Select 'Internal BOT' under Type.

Linking services with internal BOT: Configure an internal BOT to paste data from current service form to another form in a different service. Change the receiving service in the mapping page.

d) Adding actions (BOT roles) to the form
Three ways to add BOT roles: 1. To a button, 2. To an input field, 3. To a block.

BOT applied to button: Drag block, add table, add button. Click Actions, click 'click to add BOT', drag and drop action. Data and/or Document bots can be executed either in sequence or concurrently.

BOT applied to field: Action applied to a field will be executed after 1.5 seconds from occurrence of last change.

BOT applied to block: Action applied to a block will be executed after the block is rendered on the form.

2. Mapping
Mapping is the process of matching fields from one database to another.

a) Mapping between eRegistrations and GDB: Select the database from GDB with the correct version. Create map links by clicking on data on eRegistrations database then clicking on same data in GDB. Field types should match.

b) Mapping in internal BOTs: Map data between forms in the same service.

c) Mapping transformations: Logic conditions applied to mapping. Transformations include: Equals value without case-sensitive, Not equals value, Contains value, Less than value, Greater than value, Starts with, Similarity, Fuzzy, Regex expression, Nullable, Not nullable, IN.

sections.title: F. Roles
sections.content:
A role is a necessary action by a public institution for a registration to be processed.
There are 2 types of roles:
- Human role: a person will review the file, add some information, and approve, reject or send back the file.
- BOT role: an automatic processing role performed by a BOT in the system.

1. Create human roles
Click on Processing (Roles) tab, click 'add'. 'Human role' is selected by default. Activate 'Is start role in process flow' if it is the first role. Select Role Type, Activate 'Visible for applicant', enter name and short name, create.

A human role is defined by 3 elements:
a. Description: name of the role, institution in charge, registrations linked
b. Form: describes the action that will take place
c. Status: 0=pending, 1=passed successfully, 2=send back for correction, 3=rejected. Under statuses 1 and 2, must indicate destination role.

Messages at various stages: Create messages using moustache template syntax. Messages can include rejection-reasons, file-rejected mustache variables. Links can be added to messages.

2. Create BOT roles
Click 'BOT role'. Activate 'Is start role in process flow' if first role. Select preceding role. Under BOT tab, select the BOT created for the role. Mapping enables data flow to/from eRegistrations and GDB.

2.1 Polling BOT: Configure a BOT role to query the database periodically for a set amount of time. Toggle 'roles repeat until successful'. Set query interval and active duration.

3. Description of various categories of human roles
a. Revision role: obliges the operator to verify and validate documents and data before sending to next role. Documents revision and data revision tabs. Field-by-field verification can be enabled in service settings.

sections.title: G. Certificates
sections.content:
1. Build certificates
Templates/certificates for electronic results can be built in two ways:
1) Through certificate builder on the left hand side bar of user level 2: Click on 'Certificate' on the side menu, click 'Add', enter name, create. Click on the certificate name to configure it. The form builder page will appear. Click on 'cert.form' tab to build the certificate.

2) Through the registration: Choose the registration, click on 'Digital result' (green button). Activate the digital result button. Scroll down and click on 'create template'. Enter name.

The certificate form can be built just like the application form. Values for text fields can be copied from the application file or processing role through edit text field, data, copy value from. Value of expiration date can be fixed from the 'data' tab.

2. Add QR Code
The QR technology merges the physical world with the digital world. Signatures and other authentications are replaced by QR codes. They manifest the legitimacy of a document.

To add QR code on a template, drag and drop the 'QR code' from the Custom Component tab on the template.

sections.title: H. Tables
sections.content:
Tables is a list of catalogs in the system. There are three types of tables/catalogs:
1. Service catalogs (or simply tables)
2. Cross-tables
3. Instance catalogs

Service catalogs and cross-tables show data of elements related to only one service. Instance catalogs show catalogs of elements that can be applied to all services in one instance.

1. Tables/Service catalogs: they group by nature all the elements created in the services (data fields, fees, documents, institutions, units, determinants, questions, etc.). The number within brackets indicates the number of elements available.

2. Cross-tables: a way to see elements linked to each registration (data/registrations, documents/registrations, fees/registrations, roles/registration, etc.).

3. Instance catalogs: Catalogs used by all services in one instance (list of countries, cities, company types, economic activities, etc.).

a) How to create a catalog: Click 'add', type name, click 'create'. Add values by typing and clicking 'Add'. Up to 500 characters per value. Sub catalogs can be created by clicking the select button next to items. GDB based catalogs can also be created.

b) How to import a catalog with subcatalogs and/or multiple translations: Upload items modal allows downloading templates and importing modified files.

Groups: Created in catalogs with many items. Groups can be used as determinants.

c) Document rejection reasons: Create/add reasons for rejection in operators' processing page.

sections.title: I. Settings
sections.content:
1. Instance settings
Settings made in instance settings will be applied to all services in that instance. The instance settings icon is at the end of the instance menu bar.

Instance settings consist of three elements: Settings (logo, language options, currencies, footer messages, layout components), Translations, and Log out.

Options in display system: Registration link, Hide My documents tab, Hide My messages tab, Hide filter function, Hide service search function.

2. Service settings
Settings apply only to that particular service. The service settings icon is at the end of the service menu bar.

a) Pages, buttons and fields:
- Blocks and fields: Option to make blocks/fields visible in Part A and Part B based on registration linkage
- Buttons: Options to show print buttons on Guide and Part B, enabling BPA system buttons in Part B
- Page: Options for page name, preview file, file type for required documents, revision by field, show data next to document revision, show decimals for costs
- Application history, Old guide, Shopping cart, Formio version, UI theme

b) Service Options
c) Publish history
d) Export service
e) Databases

sections.title: A. The user dashboard
sections.content:
The user site or the Display System is the user dashboard.

1. For new users
The header and menu bar consists of: The home button (national logo), home button, login button, register button.

When the user clicks register, the create account page will be displayed. User provides information and clicks RegisterForAccount. Verification email will be sent.

Choice of language. The home page displays all available online services.

2. For logged in users
Menu bar consists of: home button and My Account page, name of user, choice of language.

The Home button/My Account page displays: My Applications tab (list of applications saved/submitted), My Documents tab (documents submitted), My Messages tab (messages from administrations/processing roles).

Under My Applications: service name, business name, date started, date submitted, status, certificates (can be printed from dashboard).

Filter: search for specific application by service or business name.
Application history: click on a service to see stages.
Application status shown by different colors. Status filters available at bottom.

sections.title: B. Application file (DS)
sections.content:
1. Guide
Answers provided in the Guide will help determine, for each specific user, which documents, fees and data are required.
Shopping cart: Alternative to the Guide, improved version. Shows summary of registrations, how much to pay and what documents to upload. Accessible on all pages.

2. Applicant form
This is where the applicant provides all the relevant data that pertains to his objective.

3. Documents
This is the documents upload page. This tab will appear only if documents need to be uploaded.

4. Payment
Payment tab will appear only if there is a payment in the process.

5. Send page
The confirmation page usually consists of a set of terms and conditions that the applicant needs to abide by.

sections.title: C. Operators processing pages
sections.content:
Processing pages are what operators of the institutions which offer registrations in a service see. As a super administrator, you can access the operators' processing pages from the display system (through Part B).

1. The file list page
The list of files filtered by status (pending, approved, rejected, sent back for corrections) is displayed. The drop down list displays all services. Select the service, then select the role from the first dropdown. Calendar icon allows viewing applications submitted at a certain day/time range. The first screen displays all pending files by default.

Sub menu: Status of file, Business name, Date of receipt, status of registrations, operator in charge. Status filter on bottom corner with different colors. Other filters: all files, validated, sent back, rejected.

2. The processing page
This is the 2nd screen of the operator's role. The top part displays application details (zip folder of documents) and application history.

a) Revision role: Requires operator to verify documents and data. If operator chooses 'NO' under documents revision, field appears for rejection reason. Documents revision tab shows uploaded documents on left, data and requirements on right. Data revision tab displays all components.

b) Processing role: Form/action developed by analyst. Operator can generate action (display/upload certificate). Validate, reject, or send back the application. Documents tab shows uploaded documents and certificates. Data tab shows all BPA application file components.

3. Clearing old file from the service
screenshot_descriptions: Documents and data side by side

sections.title: A. Public part
sections.content:
GDB is a system to create and administer a professional database easily, without programming. Databases created with GDB can exchange data electronically with eRegistrations and any other external system through Web services.

GDB is composed of a public part (where we see the databases created and their content) and an admin part.

The header bar consists of: Hamburger button (displays list of databases, 'create new database' and 'create new group' buttons), Name of database currently displayed, Status button (version and last updated date), Language, Logged in user.

The sub menu displays the name of the database. The 'add record' button and edit/delete icons are visible only to authorized users.

sections.title: B.1. Create a database
sections.content:
To create a database, click on the hamburger button, then click 'create new database'. Enter institution name under Title, enter short name (without spaces). Version starts at 1.0.

Create the DB structure adding fields and blocks by clicking on the '+' symbol. 'ID' appears by default as the first field. Click on the dropdown to select field type (text, number, block, date, catalog, etc.). Note: field type should be same as in BPA.

Use blocks to group records/fields together. Click 'simple view' to view basic components. Use the symbol in front to change order by dragging. Publish to save and see changes in public part.

sections.title: B.2. Database groups
sections.content:
To create a database group, click hamburger button, then 'create new group'. Enter name, optionally upload a logo. Databases can be created within groups or dragged into groups.

a) Edit Group
b) Database diagram: Visualization of how different databases within the same group relate to each other. Click on group name then diagram icon. All databases shown as blocks with relationship lines. Zoom with mouse scroll, rearrange with drag and drop. Navigation icons for layout.

c) Creating a link between databases: Click DB structure, click Settings for a field, switch toggle 'Link to other DBs' on, select database and field to link. 'L' icon indicates linked field.
subsections: c) Creating a link between databases

sections.title: B.3. Add record
sections.content:
To add a record, click 'Add record' button on sub menu. A slider opens. Enter all data, Save. The slider can be expanded or minimized by dragging the border. Records can be edited or deleted.

Field history: Click on a record to see details. History icon appears next to every field. Shows date of change, user who made change, type of action, initial value, new value. Block container history shows times table for tracing value changes by date.

sections.title: B.4. Database management section
sections.content:
The 'tools on' button displays the database management menu: Version, creation date, administrator login. Filters allow selective data viewing. Complex filters available for nested conditions. Columns tab displays selected data. Reports tab for creating/viewing reports. Import data from external files/databases. Export data in JSON, XLS, CSV formats. Log displays change history. Delete data button (irreversible).

a) Views: Subset of GDB displaying selected data defined by filters. Create view by clicking Views tab, '+' button, enter name, add filters, drag fields to 'view fields'. Publish for visibility. Complex views involving multiple databases possible through linked databases.

b) APIs: Tool for web services enabling data exchange between DS and GDB. API types: Create, Create-entries, Read, List, Update, Listen, Update-entries, Exists, Delete. Dashboard shows creation date, name, URL, usage counts. APIs versioned per database version. Visibility toggle controls BPA availability.

c) DB Structure: Modify database structure. Duplicate database. Add/delete/reorder fields. Version updates on save. Publish and remap in BPA required.

sections.title: B.5. Special features
sections.content:
a) To change format of ID: Click DB Structure, click settings cog on ID column. Advanced Settings, Triggers tab. Configure with available tags: Short name, Index no, Index no by database code, Current year, End of number current year.

b) Show catalog key in the database structure: Click Settings, activate 'Show key and value' toggle.

c) Migrate data between databases: Open target table, click 'Import Data', Database tab, Create. Select source database, drag and drop column labels to map data, click Migrate.

d) Import data to other database on trigger.

e) Setting readonly field property on GDB.

f) How to apply pattern label (regex using) on GDB.

g) How to add listing value in GDB edit grids.

h) How to compare two databases.

i) How to make a textfield into a select predefined values field.

j) Where to limit the document type accepted by the file field.

k) How to configure database file field to accept multiple files: Open DB structure, add file field, open advance settings, Base settings tab, activate Multiple toggle, publish.
subsections: g) Listing value in edit grids

sections.title: B.6. User rights in GDB
sections.content:
User rights management enables admin users to grant or take away rights and privileges to other users.

a) Introduction to user rights page: Click user button, select User management. Left side: list of registered users. Right side: rights granted to selected user.

Search an existing user or import new user from CAS or Keycloak.

Create a new user: Must be registered in CAS/KC first. Import by clicking icon next to search field, enter user ID.

Right side: rights - Resources (databases) in first column. Actions: Read, Create, Update, Publish, Delete, User rights. Toggles define actions per database.

Groups of databases: Listed under their group. Rights can be granted to group or specific database.

b) Granting right to Database structure: Read (needs Data toggle on), Update (Save button appears), Publish (Publish button appears), Delete (Delete button appears).

c) Data User rights (Generic): Read, Update (Edit button per entry), Delete (Delete button per entry).

d) Data User rights (field level restrictions): Click 'restrictions' button. Grant read/update rights to specific columns or records matching filter conditions.

e) General rules for actions toggle behavior: GREEN=fully authorised, GREY=not authorised, YELLOW=partially authorised. Parent GREEN=all children GREEN. Parent YELLOW=at least one child YELLOW or GREY. Parent GREY=all children GREY.
subsections: a) Introduction to user rights page
b) Granting right to Database structure
d) Data User rights (field level restrictions)
e) General rules for actions toggle behavior

sections.title: A. Overview
sections.content:
Statistics module is a tool for registered users to see statistical information about files and processes in eRegistrations system. It can also present KPI (Key Performance Indicators) for managers.

Panel at top enables switching between types of statistics, changing language or logging out. Every type of statistics has its own set of filters and tools.

sections.title: B. Types of statistics
sections.content:
1. Roles
Purpose: provide information about the number of files that obtained a specific status in a given service role for a defined period of time.
Filters: Filter empty rows, Show inactive services, Date field (calendar for period selection), Service filter, Registration filter, Status filter. Data can be broken down into days/weeks/months/years. Export to excel or PDF.

2. Certificates issued
Purpose: provide information about the number of certificates generated for a given service within a period.
Filters: Certificates filter (lists certificate across services).

3. Operators
Purpose: provide information on specific operator activity - number of files processed through a role, broken down into statuses (Processed, Approved, Sent back, Rejected).
Filters: Operator filter (type-ahead input), Roles filter.

4. Times per Role
Purpose: information about how much time the file spent in a given role. Shows average, minimum and maximum time for processed files.

5. Times per operator
Purpose: how much time every operator spent processing files in a given role. Shows average, minimum and maximum time.

6. Rejection reasons
Provides rejection reasons for files processed and rejected or sent back for correction in Part B revision role. Filter by service name and Status (2-Sent back, 3-Rejected). Dashboard shows: rejection reason, status code, operator, role name, date of rejection.
